awd_titl_txt: DDRIG: The Impact of Video Games, Identity, and Narrative on Understandings of  Mental Health
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to understand how video games communicate mental health narratives. It will provide insight into how digital technologies and new media are re-defining knowledge about and experiences of mental health. This study will support health care professionals, players and scholars understanding of the relationship between technology and mental health. It will broaden mental health discussions to include new spaces structured by digital technology and storytelling.


This dissertation research project aims to: (1) explore how mental health is represented and conveyed as meaningful within video games; (2) understand whether and how stories about mental health are taken up, received, and interpreted by those who engage with these games; and (3) articulate how narratives and storytelling may act as sites of power, inequality, and resistance within video game and mental health spaces. Using qualitative interviews and observations with people who play video games, in addition to critical analyses of video game texts, this study will examine how individuals’ understanding of and relationship to mental health shape and are shaped by video game narratives and experiences. This study will contribute to broadened understandings of how everyday interactions with digital technologies participate in knowledge production, specifically around health and mental health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Much of the existing scholarship on digital games and mental health focus on the positive and negative effects that games may have on discrete diagnostic categories and symptoms. Little has examined the lived experience of player mental health and its intersection with digital games. In this qualitative study, I explore the mental health of people who play games and the ways in which they create new meanings surrounding their own experiences stemming from their interaction and immersion into digital game worlds. 

 

This research advances our understanding of the landscapes of mental health and the everyday spaces in which people make sense of and find reprieve for their struggles. My participants nearly all experience isolation and stigma around their mental health and illness and many encountered barriers to accessing mental healthcare. Participants felt alone in their experience, often not knowing others that shared in their struggles or felt ostracized and shamed when disclosing their mental illness to family and friends. My findings indicate that for my participants, individuals who enjoy and have played digital games for most of their lives, digital games served as an important space to encounter others like them in the form of game characters and to participate in shared narratives that allowed them to craft new meanings, understanding, and connections surrounding their mental health and illness. 

 

The three main findings of this project are as follows: First, I interrogate digital game discourse that connects virtual embodiment to escapism and empathy. In line with other work on escapism, participants in this project play games to escape from daily stress and the weight of everyday life. At the same time, however, I argue that participants intentionally sought certain digital games and game features to elicit and create specific feelings that redressed their day-to-day anxiety, depression, and disempowerment. I also demonstrate how participants allow themselves to fully become digital game characters while at the same time remaining rooted in themselves. As participants experience this, they embed their own mental health struggles alongside digital game characters' narratives allowing them to interact and engage with their mental health in a less confrontational setting. In this way, participants form something akin to empathy and compassion toward themselves as they try on versions of their selves through characters to better explore and understand aspects of their mental health. Second, I explore a different set of relationships that participants fashion with digital game characters. I analyze the bonds that participants form with player-characters as separate social actors and find that participants construe the characters they play as experientially similar. Because participants perceive these characters to be like them, they perceive and receive social support through their gameplay. Specifically, participant connections with digital game characters help them feel less alone and to normalize their conditions, learn possible effective coping strategies, and envision an alternative future for themselves and how they relate to their mental health. Finally, I found that digital games offer a flexible, open-ended, and interpretive space for participants to explore their grief and loss. Digital games become a world of participants’ making as they identify and interpret the symbolic and metaphorically rich elements of a gameworld’s environment in ways that resonate directly with their experiences of loss. From the overarching narratives to specific interactions like moving and pressing a button to the way in which games create moments of emotional catharsis and validation, I assert that participants become the architects of the gameworlds that they inhabit, creating for themselves time, space, and permission to sit with, process and reflect on their own loss.

 

My research also contributes to the interdisciplinary study of digital games and qualitative research methods. I expanded traditional game studies by centering sociological inquiries, embedding participants’ gaming experiences within their mental health experiences and the broader landscape of the social and cultural perceptions of mental health in their communities. I also advance new methodological approaches, adapting place-based health research and user experience methods to the observation and in-depth interviewing of participants while they played different games.
